The app crashed in multiple places of the funnel starting from user registration. Sometimes crashes happened unpredictably at the time of certain user actions under certain conditions.
In some parts of the app, users experienced some slowness. Some parts of the app worked fine some were slow.

The signup experience and the matching experience weren’t seamlessly connected. Especially combined with the slowness and crashing, it was really hard to get the user seamlessly transitioning between the screens all step of the way.
“When you scale your traffic, you want to make sure your product is built right. When a user sees a crash in the app, they leave, and may never come back.”

To continue gaining some traction and to scale up the user acquisition, the product needs to be crash-free, with a smooth, easy to understand user experience. After the user downloads the app, the signup process should be as simple as entering your information on a single screen with built-in input field validation and hitting submit. Once the user signs up, they go straight to the matching experience with some optional tooltips explaining how the app works. No crashes, no slowness, just seamless screen transitions for the user to get some great user experience.

Dus team and Right Balance team worked together in a laser-focused sprint to get the app ready for launch on time for the influencer campaign. First, the Right Balance team fixed all the crashes in the app. Some of them were on the

. Once all backend endpoints were optimized, and the data was passed around in a proper format between the client and the backend, the app experience started to really shine. Some optional tooltips were added and spotlight some important sections of the app. With some additional client performance optimizations which moved the heavy network requests on the background thread, the app slowness was no longer an issue.

Once the app became solid, the company did an amazing campaign with a social influencer in the space allowing Dus to acquire over 100,000 users in the first 3 months of launch with a close to $0 customer acquisition cost. Once the product was integrated, the CEO moved on to the next opportunity at the YCombinator accelerator program.

_data.text:
Challenge

Dus is a dating mobile app focused on South Asians in your local area. The company got some initial traction and the beta users loved the app. Once the time came to acquire significantly more users, the founders found several issues with the product.

High Crash Rate

The app crashed in multiple places of the funnel starting from user registration. Sometimes crashes happened unpredictably at the time of certain user actions under certain conditions.

App Slowness

In some parts of the app, users experienced some slowness. Some parts of the app worked fine some were slow.

Complicated UX Flow

The signup experience and the matching experience weren’t seamlessly connected. Especially combined with the slowness and crashing, it was really hard to get the user seamlessly transitioning between the screens all step of the way.

Solution

“When you scale your traffic, you want to make sure your product is built right. When a user sees a crash in the app, they leave, and may never come back.”

Shawn Sheikh, CEO @ Dus

To continue gaining some traction and to scale up the user acquisition, the product needs to be crash-free, with a smooth, easy to understand user experience. After the user downloads the app, the signup process should be as simple as entering your information on a single screen with built-in input field validation and hitting submit. Once the user signs up, they go straight to the matching experience with some optional tooltips explaining how the app works. No crashes, no slowness, just seamless screen transitions for the user to get some great user experience.

Execution

Dus team and Right Balance team worked together in a laser-focused sprint to get the app ready for launch on time for the influencer campaign. First, the Right Balance team fixed all the crashes in the app. Some of them were on the [client side](/solutions/client-side-development-enlighten-your-users-with-the-best-user-experience), some were coming from the [backend api](/solutions/api-development-scale-to-millions-of-users-with-a-robust-backend). Once all backend endpoints were optimized, and the data was passed around in a proper format between the client and the backend, the app experience started to really shine. Some optional tooltips were added and spotlight some important sections of the app. With some additional client performance optimizations which moved the heavy network requests on the background thread, the app slowness was no longer an issue.

Results

Once the app became solid, the company did an amazing campaign with a social influencer in the space allowing Dus to acquire over 100,000 users in the first 3 months of launch with a close to $0 customer acquisition cost. As things progressed, Dus was acquired by Woo App in India. The company CEO and the team joined in the advisor role to integrate the product into the acquiring company. Once the product was integrated, the CEO moved on to the next opportunity at the YCombinator accelerator program.

children.value: is an amazing company on a mission to connect all learners with the people and resources needed to reach their full potential. Since 2008, Edmodo has helped over 100 million users in hundreds of thousands of schools over the world using technology. That said, over the years of rapid feature development, the current stack became outdated bringing the following challenges:

As features were developed over the years, there wasn’t enough automation put in place. This, little by little, added more manual maintenance work every sprint. Spending time away from doing the feature work slows down the overall feature velocity which is crucial for delivering business value rapidly.

framework used on the back end, combined with some excessive use of a SQL Database led to some high usage for cloud resources. A monolithic architecture is known for being easy to start with and hard to scale later down the road. With more traffic, the existing architecture and the infrastructure behind it needed to be rethought to handle the increasing user demand cost-efficiently.

The Edmodo team built an amazing product that users love using every day. With a consistent release schedule, numerous features were going out every week. "Right Balance came with a strong team of industry veterans and helped us solve issues we had for years. We’re now a high performing lean and mean team making some truly global impact on remote education."

To reduce the labor intensity and the overall cloud spent, the Right Balance team focused on two key aspects: automation and streamlined process. Both things go hand in hand. Robust automation lets the machines do repetitive work. And a strong streamlined process helps with reducing coordination and communication necessary to make the internal operations very efficient.
You can’t manage what you can’t measure

The key to managing the cost of your system is to be able to see it and have a clear action plan towards making the cloud spent as efficiently as possible. Doing so allows us to significantly reduce the monthly AWS bill and continue managing the cost of your system over time.

Being able to release any day has a huge impact on the business! With a streamlined release process, Edmodo will be able to deliver any feature into production the minute it’s ready to go instead of waiting a week for it.

The first change was to move the test running from the weekend into the week so the team has a weekend to recharge. The next step was to introduce the automatic deployment of any new changes coming into the mainline git branch, followed by the run of the acceptance test suite. Edmodo acceptance test suite has some great test coverage. It allows us to offload the existing Cucumber test suite and eventually migrate it towards the new stack with Postman and Cypress. In addition to it, running mocked UI tests became a lot faster. Which in turn enabled the QA team to write more precise tests covering some additional corner cases.
A third piece of the puzzle is contract testing using

. Now that the client and the backend are tested individually, some robust contract tests guarantee that the version of the backend is compatible with the corresponding version of the front end. Added bonus: contract tests run a lot faster than traditional end-to-end tests saving you precious engineering time.
Track, Analyze, and Reduce AWS Spent

technologies. Last but not least, we added some application-level caching reducing the load on the databases, hence lowering down database instance size.

_data.text:
Challenge

[Edmodo](https://edmodo.com "Edmodo") is an amazing company on a mission to connect all learners with the people and resources needed to reach their full potential. Since 2008, Edmodo has helped over 100 million users in hundreds of thousands of schools over the world using technology. That said, over the years of rapid feature development, the current stack became outdated bringing the following challenges:

Development Velocity Slowdown

As features were developed over the years, there wasn’t enough automation put in place. This, little by little, added more manual maintenance work every sprint. Spending time away from doing the feature work slows down the overall feature velocity which is crucial for delivering business value rapidly.

High AWS Bill

A monolithic nature of the [Ruby on Rails](https://rubyonrails.org/) framework used on the back end, combined with some excessive use of a SQL Database led to some high usage for cloud resources. A monolithic architecture is known for being easy to start with and hard to scale later down the road. With more traffic, the existing architecture and the infrastructure behind it needed to be rethought to handle the increasing user demand cost-efficiently.

Labor Intensive Release Process

The Edmodo team built an amazing product that users love using every day. With a consistent release schedule, numerous features were going out every week. That said, the whole process involves cross-team communication and coordination across different time zones. The release process also involves a large number of QA engineers, DevOps engineers, some developers working together to deliver every release to production, taking away the time from feature development. To continue further expansion and innovation, Edmodo needed to bring their technology and process to the next level.

Solution

"Right Balance came with a strong team of industry veterans and helped us solve issues we had for years. We’re now a high performing lean and mean team making some truly global impact on remote education."

Elmar Mamedov, CTO @ Edmodo

To reduce the labor intensity and the overall cloud spent, the Right Balance team focused on two key aspects: automation and streamlined process. Both things go hand in hand. Robust automation lets the machines do repetitive work. And a strong streamlined process helps with reducing coordination and communication necessary to make the internal operations very efficient.

Track and Reduce AWS Spent

> You can’t manage what you can’t measure > - Peter Drucker The key to managing the cost of your system is to be able to see it and have a clear action plan towards making the cloud spent as efficiently as possible. Doing so allows us to significantly reduce the monthly AWS bill and continue managing the cost of your system over time.

Streamline Release Process

Being able to release any day has a huge impact on the business! With a streamlined release process, Edmodo will be able to deliver any feature into production the minute it’s ready to go instead of waiting a week for it.

CI/CD Pipeline

Your CI/CD pipeline minimizes the manual work necessary to ship steady releases frequently. It brings consistency and encourages building a robust set of automated tests as a long-lasting investment into your system.

Execution

Right Balance team and Edmodo staff work together to attack the current challenges on multiple fronts.

From Weekly to Daily Releases

With the goal set to be able to release any day, Right Balance worked together with multiple department heads from Edmodo to design, implement, and provide training for existing personnel on a new way of releasing daily. #### Process The current process was cutting a release tag by the end of the week, running the acceptance tests over the weekend, fixing issues at the beginning of the next week, and releasing mid-week. The first change was to move the test running from the weekend into the week so the team has a weekend to recharge. The next step was to introduce the automatic deployment of any new changes coming into the mainline git branch, followed by the run of the acceptance test suite. All of which used to happen only once a week for multiple features in the release. #### Infrastructure Partnering with a stellar DevOps accelerator called [CloudPosse](http://cloudposse.com/), Right Balance produced a state of the art [Kubernetes](https://kubernetes.io/) infrastructure created with [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) and the rest of [CloudPosse’s Open Source cloud tools](https://github.com/cloudposse). Once the main runway was put together, each backend application was migrated over to the new runway gaining some amazing consistency for services configuration and provisioning. In addition to it, comprehensive monitoring was put in place, as well as auto-scaling elasticity, and the version control for the infrastructure templates. #### CI/CD Edmodo acceptance test suite has some great test coverage. That said, with the absence of mocking and with the growing number of edge cases to test, the suite quickly grew into 880 feature scenarios running for 1.5 hours with some mixed results. To speed up the existing acceptance tests and to make the test more robust, we introduced API level tests. We took the existing end to end tests written in [Cucumber](https://cucumber.io/) and [Selenium](https://www.selenium.dev/), and split them into two groups of tests: 1. API level tests using [Postman](http://getpostman.com/) 2. Mocked UI tests using [Cypress](https://www.cypress.io/) It allows us to offload the existing Cucumber test suite and eventually migrate it towards the new stack with Postman and Cypress. In addition to it, running mocked UI tests became a lot faster. Which in turn enabled the QA team to write more precise tests covering some additional corner cases. A third piece of the puzzle is contract testing using [Pact](https://pact.io). Now that the client and the backend are tested individually, some robust contract tests guarantee that the version of the backend is compatible with the corresponding version of the front end. Added bonus: contract tests run a lot faster than traditional end-to-end tests saving you precious engineering time.

Track, Analyze, and Reduce AWS Spent

We went from $600,000 a month down to $300,000 a month. How is it possible? The key is to have hard numbers that you can analyze and keep track of keeping your AWS as low as possible. First things first, we did a full inventory audit of the existing infrastructure including server instances, databases, buckets, etc. Next, we created a cost dashboard using [AWS QuickSight](https://aws.amazon.com/quicksight/). This way we can track and visualize the AWS spent. Equipped with some hard numbers, we created a battle plan to remove the unnecessary resources, downscale some overscaled resources, introduce elasticity to the picture using [Aurora Serverless](https://aws.amazon.com/rds/aurora/serverless/) and the rest of the [Serverless](https://aws.amazon.com/serverless/) technologies. Last but not least, we added some application-level caching reducing the load on the databases, hence lowering down database instance size.

Build vs Buy

A build vs buy decision always comes down to using your core competency as the competitive advantage. After doing an audit of the internal systems, we found out several homegrown systems that can be completely eliminated with the use of modern technologies and external services. The homegrown search was replaced by [Algolia](https://www.algolia.com/). So as the homegrown CI was easily replaced with [Github Actions](https://github.com/features/actions). Doing so lowered the AWS bill, reduced the amount of maintenance overhead for the engineering team, and allowed Edmodo to use the industry known solutions.

Results

Edmodo’s mission is impactful and inspiring. With a strong company culture, people are passionate about what they do. They work together towards a common goal: bringing accessible education to the masses. Right Balance engagement took Edmodo technology and process to the next level. Modernization of the Edmodo tech stack led to a $350,000 monthly reduction in AWS bill, 30% decrease in maintenance overhead for existing systems, simple to understand architecture using the modern technologies of today. It’s easier to hire creative and forward-thinking professionals excited to work with the new technology which increases team productivity and propels innovation.

_data.title: Data is Key: How Fair Revolutionizes Car Ownership using the Highest Precision Data

toc.text: Preventing Discrepancies in the First Place
Make Existing Unit Tests Rock Solid

children.value: is one of the hottest startups in Los Angeles. Raised over $2.1B in total funding Fair simplified the car leasing process so anyone can do it all from the app. Fair is one of the great examples of how to use technology to streamline the lengthy process of leasing a car.

As the company scaled rapidly, with the quickly growing amount of data, it’s important to maintain data integrity. Making business decisions based on real and meaningful data is key in today’s world. That being said, there were several challenges to overcome to maintain proper data integrity.
Information is the oil of the 21st century, and analytics is the combustion engine.
As more microservices were written the data became more fragmented. As the data grew, it became harder to validate data integrity across multiple databases.

to support the increased scaling needs. New microservices communicate with each other through a messaging channel. While the messaging between microservices works most of the time, in some cases some messages were dropped, failed, or retried multiple times causing some data discrepancies. At scale the discrepancies become noticeable.
What used to happen in a single process in a monolith, now happened across multiple microservices. To make sure the data update remains idempotent new controls need to be implemented.
“Data integrity is key to making data-driven business decisions. With the latest data validation framework and idempotency controls in place, we’re able to guarantee our data accuracy.”
Michelle Yung, Director of Engineering @ Fair
To solve this problem, we executed on the following major areas:

A clear set of steps allowing to validate the data across multiple databases needed to be implemented. Once the framework is in place, we can run it at any time, to verify the data, and to discover discrepancies.
Preventing Discrepancies in the First Place

Now that the issues are discovered by the validation framework, we can go back and implement the changes to prevent it from happening again. Doing so allows us to fix the issue, establish a higher standard of software development on the team, and adding some additional automated tests running continuously testing the system.
Make Existing Unit Tests Rock Solid

One of the qualities of a great unit test suite is producing a reliable result. Fixing and eliminating flaky tests is crucial in making a robust unit test suite. Each test has to be idempotent, isolated, and consistent to bring the benefits of automated testing every time you run it.

First things first, the data discrepancies were identified by doing some heavy SQL analysis across all databases. Several of the discrepancies were fixed right away. As we dove deeper we created tickets for the rest of the discrepancies to be fixed going forward. Once the SQL queries were written, a new library was created with an accompanying spreadsheet for doing a final check. Doing so allows us to execute the data validation in a repeatable manner. And there is a clear path towards improving this solution to eliminate more manual steps and make the whole process completely automatic.
We focused on preventing the discrepancies earlier in the process by introducing idempotency locks using

. As the data transaction happens, an automatic validation was implemented allowing microservices to synchronize their data transformation process preventing duplicates, and triggering the retries for missed pieces of information. The process of implementing some robust automatic data validation became a standard for the engineering team. Several data validation patterns were implemented for everyone to follow and to apply to the rest of the system.

Writing a great unit test is an art of its own. Fixing and eliminating some flaky tests, making sure the tests operate on a randomized data set every time they run significantly increased the overall quality of the test suite. We also made sure each test doesn’t affect the results of the next test down the stream by adding test order randomization. Last but not least, we extracted some of the most common setup code into a reusable testing infrastructure and laid out the foundation for writing some robust test cases going forward.

After implementing the solution, Fair has a repeatable framework in place to verify the data across multiple databases at any time. This framework reduces the manual time it took to reconcile the data by 50%. Adding distributed Redis locks to microservices helped to reduce the data duplicates by 90% reducing the amount of effort needed to clean the data after the fact. With all known discrepancies addressed and new controls implemented, Fair has some crystal clear and precise data used for making some key business decisions, going through the compliance process, and continuing to delight their customers. This effort set an example of how to automate even more of the manual work out of the process. Making the entire software system more robust by establishing and documenting high-quality software development standards for developing distributed systems.

_data.text:
Challenge

[Fair](https://www.fair.com/) is one of the hottest startups in Los Angeles. Raised over $2.1B in total funding Fair simplified the car leasing process so anyone can do it all from the app. Fair is one of the great examples of how to use technology to streamline the lengthy process of leasing a car. As the company scaled rapidly, with the quickly growing amount of data, it’s important to maintain data integrity. Making business decisions based on real and meaningful data is key in today’s world. That being said, there were several challenges to overcome to maintain proper data integrity. > Information is the oil of the 21st century, and analytics is the combustion engine. > - Peter Sondergaard, Gartner Research

Integrity Validation

As more microservices were written the data became more fragmented. As the data grew, it became harder to validate data integrity across multiple databases.

Data Transmission Robustness

Fair migrated from the [monolithic architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monolithic_application) to [microservices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microservices) to support the increased scaling needs. New microservices communicate with each other through a messaging channel. While the messaging between microservices works most of the time, in some cases some messages were dropped, failed, or retried multiple times causing some data discrepancies. At scale the discrepancies become noticeable.

Lack of Idempotency Controls

What used to happen in a single process in a monolith, now happened across multiple microservices. To make sure the data update remains idempotent new controls need to be implemented.

Solution

“Data integrity is key to making data-driven business decisions. With the latest data validation framework and idempotency controls in place, we’re able to guarantee our data accuracy.”

Michelle Yung, Director of Engineering @ Fair

To solve this problem, we executed on the following major areas:

Creating a Data Validation Framework

A clear set of steps allowing to validate the data across multiple databases needed to be implemented. Once the framework is in place, we can run it at any time, to verify the data, and to discover discrepancies.

Preventing Discrepancies in the First Place

Now that the issues are discovered by the validation framework, we can go back and implement the changes to prevent it from happening again. Doing so allows us to fix the issue, establish a higher standard of software development on the team, and adding some additional automated tests running continuously testing the system.

Make Existing Unit Tests Rock Solid

One of the qualities of a great unit test suite is producing a reliable result. Fixing and eliminating flaky tests is crucial in making a robust unit test suite. Each test has to be idempotent, isolated, and consistent to bring the benefits of automated testing every time you run it.

Execution

Validation Framework

First things first, the data discrepancies were identified by doing some heavy SQL analysis across all databases. Several of the discrepancies were fixed right away. As we dove deeper we created tickets for the rest of the discrepancies to be fixed going forward. Once the SQL queries were written, a new library was created with an accompanying spreadsheet for doing a final check. Doing so allows us to execute the data validation in a repeatable manner. And there is a clear path towards improving this solution to eliminate more manual steps and make the whole process completely automatic.

Addressing Discrepancies

We focused on preventing the discrepancies earlier in the process by introducing idempotency locks using [Redis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redis). As the data transaction happens, an automatic validation was implemented allowing microservices to synchronize their data transformation process preventing duplicates, and triggering the retries for missed pieces of information. The process of implementing some robust automatic data validation became a standard for the engineering team. Several data validation patterns were implemented for everyone to follow and to apply to the rest of the system.

Quality Unit Tests

Writing a great unit test is an art of its own. Fixing and eliminating some flaky tests, making sure the tests operate on a randomized data set every time they run significantly increased the overall quality of the test suite. We also made sure each test doesn’t affect the results of the next test down the stream by adding test order randomization. Last but not least, we extracted some of the most common setup code into a reusable testing infrastructure and laid out the foundation for writing some robust test cases going forward.

Results

After implementing the solution, Fair has a repeatable framework in place to verify the data across multiple databases at any time. This framework reduces the manual time it took to reconcile the data by 50%. Adding distributed Redis locks to microservices helped to reduce the data duplicates by 90% reducing the amount of effort needed to clean the data after the fact. With all known discrepancies addressed and new controls implemented, Fair has some crystal clear and precise data used for making some key business decisions, going through the compliance process, and continuing to delight their customers. This effort set an example of how to automate even more of the manual work out of the process. Making the entire software system more robust by establishing and documenting high-quality software development standards for developing distributed systems.

_data.title: From Monolith to Serverless Microservices: How Tuition.io Disrupts $1.52 Trillion Student Debt Industry with New Technology
_data.header_two: of student loan debt served each month with new system

children.value: Tuition.io brings student loan repayment benefits to the nation’s best companies to free their employees from student debt. With such a fantastic mission, the company realized that the current technology doesn’t support rapid growth and scale. The current V1 system had several disadvantages:

The current solution was a monolithic system built on Laravel PHP running on a large number of legacy EC2 machines and many separate database servers. The monolithic structure wasn’t stable, it was error-prone, expensive to run, and inefficient to scale.

Due to high data fragmentation, there was no easy way to get crucial business metrics across the company. In addition to it, a lengthy ETL process was introducing a data processing delay preventing the company from answering some crucial business questions fast.
Several major business functions required manual intervention from an engineer. This, in turn, slowed down feature development and introduced more communication overhead between some team members.
The V1 infrastructure helped the company in the early days to be agile. To take the business to the next level, a technological transformation needed to take place.

To set up the business for success, Tuition.io needed a streamlined system built with the latest technology. Once the major business processes are streamlined, most of the engineering resources can be spent on developing new features delivering more value to the customers. The look and feel of the product needed to be updated to delight the customers. In addition to it, providing visibility into the system with a simple and intuitive web and native mobile interface without requiring engineering intervention is key to be able to scale.
“In this day and age, the speed of delivery is everything. What took months to deliver now takes days and hours on the V2 system.”
Bob Wall, VP of Engineering @ Tuition.io

When it comes to moving from a fragile monolithic system to microservices with increased resiliency and scalability, there are 2 major approaches: a full rebuild or a gradual migration. Since the look and feel of the product also needed to be changed in addition to increasing the scalability of the product, it made sense to go with a full rebuild of the product. Over 12 months, The Right Balance and the Tuition.io engineering team worked together to rebuild the current system.
Starting from a stunning look and feel on the

, most of the components were modularised allowing to reuse the existing code, decreasing the ongoing maintenance. Once the foundational components were built, it was very straightforward to achieve a consistent look of the product throughout the website as well as on the mobile app for iOS and Android. We used a

to be able to share the same components across different websites and it worked beautifully. Customer support representatives, the end-users, as well as the clients, can now see some consistent UI across the board which makes operations so much easier.
On the backend, a comprehensive data model laid out the foundation for a modular service layer and an

. Each microservice is independent and can solve its task efficiently. Microservices communicate between each other forming a strong resilient system where an outage of a single component allows the rest of the system to function as normal. Using
and AWS Lambda lowered the AWS bill to the minimum. It also set up the company to handle any imaginable scale.
In addition to the development tools, a state of the art
was implemented allowing developers to focus on coding and utilize a continuous integration technology to run
1,342 unit tests, 320 API tests, 43 UI tests
on every code push and to deploy multiple times a day on demand.

Once the new system was built, the migration tools were implemented to migrate the existing clients from V1 into V2 system seamlessly maintaining the data integrity. Once the data was transformed from the old format into the new format and loaded automatically, the users were able to log in seamlessly, enjoying the whole new look of the site as well as the new exciting features.

Since the web apps were written in Vue.js, using NativeScript for mobile apps was a natural choice. Using the same programming language and technologies everyone on the team is already familiar with, the new apps delivered some great experience for the users. iOS and Android users were able to log in to their accounts and manage their student loans from the convenience of their mobile phones. Important to note that both native apps (iOS and Android) were produced from a single codebase which reduces the maintenance overhead.

Today, Tuition.io runs on the new system constantly onboarding new clients, servicing millions of dollars of student loan debt each month. The system is built with the latest technologies including AWS Lambda, API Gateway, Vue.js, Node.js with Typescript, and NativeScript for mobile apps. The company was also able to cut their AWS AWS bill by 74% using Serverless technology. With Serverless, Tuition.io only pays for resources used as opposed to paying for idling servers in the past. Company engineers enjoy working in a modern technology stack producing some high-quality code every day. In addition, the product has a great smooth user experience with high visibility into the data. Employees have a clear picture of their student debt situation. Employers understand how their employees are doing in terms of their financial wellness. Tuition.io operational staff can solve customer support issues as well as onboard new clients effectively without requiring some manual intervention from engineering. Data Analysts have a clear view of the business allowing the stakeholders to make data-driven decisions.

_data.text:
Challenge

Tuition.io brings student loan repayment benefits to the nation’s best companies to free their employees from student debt. With such a fantastic mission, the company realized that the current technology doesn’t support rapid growth and scale. The current V1 system had several disadvantages:

Outdated Monolithic Architecture

The current solution was a monolithic system built on Laravel PHP running on a large number of legacy EC2 machines and many separate database servers. The monolithic structure wasn’t stable, it was error-prone, expensive to run, and inefficient to scale.

Low Visibility Into The System

Due to high data fragmentation, there was no easy way to get crucial business metrics across the company. In addition to it, a lengthy ETL process was introducing a data processing delay preventing the company from answering some crucial business questions fast.

No Streamlined Process

Several major business functions required manual intervention from an engineer. This, in turn, slowed down feature development and introduced more communication overhead between some team members. The V1 infrastructure helped the company in the early days to be agile. To take the business to the next level, a technological transformation needed to take place.

Solution

To set up the business for success, Tuition.io needed a streamlined system built with the latest technology. Once the major business processes are streamlined, most of the engineering resources can be spent on developing new features delivering more value to the customers. The look and feel of the product needed to be updated to delight the customers. In addition to it, providing visibility into the system with a simple and intuitive web and native mobile interface without requiring engineering intervention is key to be able to scale.

“In this day and age, the speed of delivery is everything. What took months to deliver now takes days and hours on the V2 system.”

Bob Wall, VP of Engineering @ Tuition.io

Execution

When it comes to moving from a fragile monolithic system to microservices with increased resiliency and scalability, there are 2 major approaches: a full rebuild or a gradual migration. Since the look and feel of the product also needed to be changed in addition to increasing the scalability of the product, it made sense to go with a full rebuild of the product. Over 12 months, The Right Balance and the Tuition.io engineering team worked together to rebuild the current system.

Componentized Front End

Starting from a stunning look and feel on the [front end](/solutions/client-side-development-enlighten-your-users-with-the-best-user-experience), most of the components were modularised allowing to reuse the existing code, decreasing the ongoing maintenance. Once the foundational components were built, it was very straightforward to achieve a consistent look of the product throughout the website as well as on the mobile app for iOS and Android. We used a [Monorepo](http://alextamoykin.com/monorepo-one-repo-to-rule-them-all) to be able to share the same components across different websites and it worked beautifully. Customer support representatives, the end-users, as well as the clients, can now see some consistent UI across the board which makes operations so much easier.

Serverless Microservices on the Backend

On the backend, a comprehensive data model laid out the foundation for a modular service layer and an [easy to use API](/solutions/api-development-scale-to-millions-of-users-with-a-robust-backend). Each microservice is independent and can solve its task efficiently. Microservices communicate between each other forming a strong resilient system where an outage of a single component allows the rest of the system to function as normal. Using [Serverless](/solutions/serverless-software-development-focus-on-features-instead-of-the-infrastructure) and AWS Lambda lowered the AWS bill to the minimum. It also set up the company to handle any imaginable scale.

Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery

In addition to the development tools, a state of the art [CI/CD pipeline](/solutions/ci-cd-like-ac-dc-rock-n-roll-with-continuous-integration-and-continuous-delivery) was implemented allowing developers to focus on coding and utilize a continuous integration technology to run [1,342 unit tests, 320 API tests, 43 UI tests](/solutions/automated-tests-get-dividends-with-every-test-run) on every code push and to deploy multiple times a day on demand.

Data Migration

Once the new system was built, the migration tools were implemented to migrate the existing clients from V1 into V2 system seamlessly maintaining the data integrity. Once the data was transformed from the old format into the new format and loaded automatically, the users were able to log in seamlessly, enjoying the whole new look of the site as well as the new exciting features.

Mobile

Since the web apps were written in Vue.js, using NativeScript for mobile apps was a natural choice. Using the same programming language and technologies everyone on the team is already familiar with, the new apps delivered some great experience for the users. iOS and Android users were able to log in to their accounts and manage their student loans from the convenience of their mobile phones. Important to note that both native apps (iOS and Android) were produced from a single codebase which reduces the maintenance overhead.

Results

Today, Tuition.io runs on the new system constantly onboarding new clients, servicing millions of dollars of student loan debt each month. The system is built with the latest technologies including AWS Lambda, API Gateway, Vue.js, Node.js with Typescript, and NativeScript for mobile apps. The company was also able to cut their AWS AWS bill by 74% using Serverless technology. With Serverless, Tuition.io only pays for resources used as opposed to paying for idling servers in the past. Company engineers enjoy working in a modern technology stack producing some high-quality code every day. In addition, the product has a great smooth user experience with high visibility into the data. Employees have a clear picture of their student debt situation. Employers understand how their employees are doing in terms of their financial wellness. Tuition.io operational staff can solve customer support issues as well as onboard new clients effectively without requiring some manual intervention from engineering. Data Analysts have a clear view of the business allowing the stakeholders to make data-driven decisions.

_data.text:
Challenge

In today’s world, most of the software is developed in the cloud. After seeing software developers spending countless hours dealing with multiple cloud technologies and providers, it was crystal clear that there needs to be a solution to it. Right Balance partnered with [Commandeer](https://getcommandeer.com "Commandeer"), to solve the cloud management problem in the modern age once and for all.

Solution

“When the solution is built right from the start, it just works, and scaling it is easy.”

Alex Tamoykin, CEO @ Commandeer

The solution came together naturally.

Desktop app

A desktop application running natively on developers’ computers, giving you a clear view of your entire infrastructure and your data. It automates some most common plumbing tasks and saves a lot of time for developers.

Website

Software developers need to be able to download the app, install it on their computer, and use it. This means that we need to develop an accompanying website with the download page and some marketing materials for the product.

CMS for Static Content

Last but not least, each software developer solution comes with some great documentation, tutorials, and educational content. To enable effortless writing, content management, and distribution, we need the documentation site with a CMS.

Execution

Cross-Platform Desktop Solution with Electron.js

Since developers use different operating systems to develop their software, the solution needs to work on macOS, Windows, and Linux. Which led us to use [Electron.js](https://www.electronjs.org/), allowing us to deliver each app from a single codebase. [ElectronBuilder](https://www.electron.build/) project provides us with the ability to build an app for each platform. This way we can make it available for download from the website. In addition to it, it allows us to build the App Store distribution for each platform. All major cross-platform apps like [Slack](https://slack.com/), [Atom](https://atom.io/), [VSCode](https://code.visualstudio.com/), etc, are developed using Electron.

Modular and Robust web components with Vue.js & Typescript

[Vue.js](https://vuejs.org/) allows us to maximize code reuse by building reusable components. Vue (similarly to [React.js](https://reactjs.org/)) has a very clean syntax combining HTML, CSS, and Javascript into a single file for each component. In addition to it, we use [Typescript](https://www.typescriptlang.org/) to write some robust code. Typescript brings us most of the features of modern programming languages like the static type system, inheritance, interfaces, and more. Best of all, using the Typescript compiler helps us to identify the issues earlier in the process so we can address them while developing our features.

Cost-Efficient API with Serverless, AWS Lambda, and AppSync

When it comes to the backend API, we want to make sure it runs as efficiently as possible. Serverless technology like [AWS Lambda](https://aws.amazon.com/lambda/) allows us to minimize idling time so we pay only for the time when the request is processed. In addition to using a traditional [API Gateway](https://aws.amazon.com/api-gateway/), we brought in the use of a more flexible [GraphQL API](https://graphql.org/) using [AWS AppSync](https://aws.amazon.com/appsync/). This way we can issue some flexible queries to our backend from the app allowing us to get the data we need fast. The data is cached properly on the client so we minimize the number of network calls.

Payments with Stripe

[Stripe](https://stripe.com/) payment integration makes collecting payments very easy. We wanted to have a consistent look and feel between the app and the payment flow, so we used [Stripe Elements](https://stripe.com/payments/elements). Doing so, allows us to add the support for coupons as well as for the annual pricing.

Documentation site in VuePress with Forestry CMS

The key to publishing some great content is to make writing effortless. Our goal is to enable us to just write the content and let the system handle the rest. That’s where [VuePress](https://vuepress.vuejs.org/) is a natural choice. As a Vue.js powered static site generator, VuePress allows us to write content using Markdown. Combined with the [Forestry](https://forestry.io/) CMS, and our build pipeline powered by [CircleCI](https://circleci.com/), we now have a fully static website without any backend and perfectly indexable by search engines.

Landing pages with Nuxt.js

Since the landing pages don’t have a lot of words per page, we needed to make several fine-tune [search engine optimizations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_engine_optimization) (SEO) which are very straightforward to do using [Nuxt.js](https://nuxtjs.org/). In addition to it, Nuxt is built on top of Vue.js allowing us to reuse some existing components. With Nuxt.js we get the best of both worlds. We get all the power of Vue.js framework and a statically generated pre-rendered website that is heavily optimized for search engine crawlers.

JAMStack All The Way

By utilizing [JAMStack](https://jamstack.org/) to build our websites, we were able to have close to 99% uptime. Now adding Serverless into the mix brings our overhead costs down to a minimum. Here, we’re leaning on the latest technologies and the existing services and APIs to maximize the development velocity and minimize the monthly costs and maintenance overhead.

Results

Today, Commandeer is used Worldwide in 100+ countries organically. Because the problem is solved for the target audience so well, the app is naturally discovered by developers online. Using word of mouth, the users recommend it to their colleagues as a great tool to have under their belt. Commandeer runs with close to $0 in cloud spent because of the use of Serverless and JAMStack architecture. The websites are optimized for speed regardless of the user location in the world. Website content is easily searchable by the major search engine crawlers bringing some consistent organic traffic to the site. If you would like us to build a SaaS solution with low overhead costs and high efficiency, don’t hesitate to reach out.

_data.title: Leveraging AWS Lambda to Drive Product Growth at Tala

children.value: Authors: Rachel Brown (Product Manager) and Alex Tamoykin (Tech Lead), originally posted on

In 2019, Tala’s Product and Engineering teams partnered with Right Balance to solve a number of complex problems for our business and our customers in emerging markets. In this article, we share how a new architectural design helped us drive sustainable growth for the company as well as solve one of our customers’ top pain points.
The new architectural design we built involves SQS queues and AWS lambda functions. We decided to use this design because of several factors:

Each event has business value, so we wanted to ensure that no events are dropped under heavy traffic. Placing events on a durable SQS queue as they occur allows us to retain them as well as retry delivering them in case of a processing failure.
One of the main advantages of serverless technology is the ability to use resources on demand. AWS lambdas are only billed at the times when they are invoked.
Managing events in a queue and lambdas allows us to swap out each component easily, which opens up more possibilities for future use cases.

Like many businesses, Tala’s marketing team uses digital advertising channels to introduce our product to new audiences. Early last year, the effectiveness of Tala’s Facebook and Google ads were being primarily measured by install events (i.e., users who download the app). We quickly identified an opportunity to improve the effectiveness of campaigns by optimizing ads for post-install events rather than downloads.

props.alt: Alex and Rachel at Tala’s HQ in Santa Monica, CA.

children.value: Alex and Rachel at Tala’s HQ in Santa Monica, CA.

The marketing team identified several high-priority post-install events, which we set up triggers for on backend services. When an event is triggered, a file is sent to an SQS queue. The lambda function then retrieves this information from the queue and passes it to our marketing platform API. This architecture is much more resilient and accurate than the team’s previous client-side event tracking solution.

Tala’s engineering team designed, built, and tested the new framework over several sprints. Our marketing team then ran a scaled Facebook campaign and realized a significantly higher return on ad spend when optimizing for post-install events compared to install events, in addition to maintaining 100% uptime and data accuracy.

In emerging markets such as Kenya, the second-hand phone market is massive. Consumers are also sensitive to download and storage size due to device and data constraints. Because Tala uses device data (with user permission) to underwrite personal loans, the following is a common scenario:
Person A installs app on phone and signs up for Tala
Person A sells phone to Person B
Person B cannot sign up for Tala on phone

Tala’s legacy device management rules, used to prevent fraud, were blocking tens of thousands of new users per month from signing up and were one of the largest drivers of customer support tickets globally. In addition, this problem had grown 3x in volume over the past 2 years and was expected to continue increasing exponentially the longer the company operated in a given market.

In this situation, we launched a set of new device management rules and a lambda function. The lambda stored a large amount of event data in a predefined format in a Cassandra database. Doing some pre-processing of the data upfront allowed us to achieve constant database lookups to identify the device ownership instantly. We enabled new users to more seamlessly sign up for the app while decreasing customer support tickets related to device issues by 91%.

As thought workers and entrepreneurs, we solve challenging problems every day. As you scale your business, which used to work in the past needs to be challenged and rethought. Using the right technology the right way helps you break through the limits and take your product to the next level.

_data.title: API Development: Scale to Millions of Users With a Robust Backend
_data.cta_header: Have any questions about Backend API?

children.value: Your backend API is a combination of your application servers, databases, and your infrastructure powering your client-side applications or your API consumers. A properly implemented backend API allows you to drink your IPA while your entire system works for you.
Here is what a typical API looks like:

When a client request comes from a web browser, mobile app, or a third party, the first place it goes to is an API Gateway. The goal of API Gateway is to route the request to a specific destination, which is a microservice most of the time. Depending on the API Gateway implementation, it can also handle user authentication and some request transformation before handing it off to the microservice. Last but not least, API Gateway handles the first level of security by routing a request coming from the public Internet to a private resource. Important to note that all resources behind the API Gateway like your microservices and database should remain private and not being exposed to the Internet. Only API Gateway should have the ability to route the right request from the public to the private territory.

That’s where the magic happens. Most of your business logic is contained at this level. If you have microservices architecture, different requests will go to different microservices. Depending on your use-case, your service can do any number of things like making a database query, calling another microservice or a 3rd party API, caching some data for future use, writing into a queue, or performing some computation.

A properly architected system is at the core of a robust and scalable API. If your API is architected well, everything else comes together naturally. Your product will be able to support your level of traffic and you’ll have a lot of happy customers.
When designing your API, you’ll need to minimize the following:
A number of single points of failure (which is a database in most cases).
A number of internal calls between services.

The main thing to realize is that each call results in a chain of events. While the work is happening the user is waiting for a response. Time and time again we’ve seen a seemingly quick API call taking a long time or sometimes taking the system down. Everyone on the team needs to have a clear idea of which calls are made for each operation and which resources are used during each call. There are a lot of tools out there like
that help you measure the timing of each individual call between services. You’ll be able to fix the issues before the software gets pushed to prod by instrumenting your app and running some
against it in your testing environment.
Once the system is architected for scale, supporting more traffic or less traffic should be as simple as a configuration change. Here are the main things to consider:
Most of the cloud providers have auto-scaling capabilities based on certain rules you can specify. In addition to it, we recommend looking into

allowing for scaling automatically with the increase or decrease in traffic. If your server provisioning is manual at the moment, it’s worth thinking about automating it. This way you can spend your engineering resources on developing new features or improving the strength of the overall system instead of manually provisioning servers.

Especially with microservices, it’s easy to fall into a trap of ‘nano services’. Making your services too granular can lead to an increase in the number of inner service calls. It’s a good idea to avoid making one service call another service and so on and so forth. The longer the call chain, the greater the possibility of a failure at each step, and the overall call length increases too. In addition to it, debugging a call spanning across multiple services is much harder than debugging a single call to a single service.

Alerting and monitoring is your best friend. It should be a part of the requirement for every feature. When your alerting and monitoring are properly set up you sleep better at night. It allows you to be more proactive about fixing the issues before they become problems. If something goes wrong, you’ll get notified and you’ll stay ahead of the game. This also increases the accountability of your team. The systems need to be developed so they always work without human intervention.
A great book on a subject is

Your backend API is what makes your system scale to support a large number of users. With the increase in traffic comes the increase in cost. Therefore, when building your backend, you should be aware of the cost implications of your implementation decisions. We recommend focusing on the following areas:

The main purpose of your operational database is to serve the immediate API requests. Anything else adds to the database size, decreases the database availability, and makes scaling the database harder, especially for SQL databases.

Depending on your use-case, you’ll need a number of different environments. For a simple scenario having just 3 environments works just fine (development, staging, and production). As your organization grows, you’ll have more use cases you need to support and the number of environments will grow too. The key here is to have all production and pre-production environments with the same configuration. And all the rest of the systems with a scaled-down version of your resources to keep the cost down. In addition to it, using Serverless or Containers helps to minimize idle server time.
Using the right tool for the job

We’ve seen many cases where a SQL database stores all application logs, acts as a search index for different kinds of queries, and even acts as a data warehouse while providing data for the API requests. There are solutions made specifically for each type of problem to solve. Logs can be archived into some flat files and processed offline. There are plenty of search solutions like

. A data warehouse needs to be separate from your runtime operational database so your data analyst doesn’t bring your runtime system down. Plus data warehouse users need the data in a different format. When using the right solution for each type of problem, you’ll be able to provide a better experience for the users. You’ll also have better control over your system cost.

Your backend infrastructure is the heart of your system. It supports your client applications at scale. Architecting your backend system right makes everything else easier. Using the right tool for the job is key. There are specialized solutions for each type of problem. The goal is to build it so it always works with some comprehensive alerting and monitoring in place notifying you about the issues in advance. If you need some help with building a robust backend API, don’t hesitate to reach out.

_data.text:
## What is Backend API

Your backend API is a combination of your application servers, databases, and your infrastructure powering your client-side applications or your API consumers. A properly implemented backend API allows you to drink your IPA while your entire system works for you.

## API Anatomy

Here is what a typical API looks like:

### API Gateway

When a client request comes from a web browser, mobile app, or a third party, the first place it goes to is an API Gateway. The goal of API Gateway is to route the request to a specific destination, which is a microservice most of the time. Depending on the API Gateway implementation, it can also handle user authentication and some request transformation before handing it off to the microservice. Last but not least, API Gateway handles the first level of security by routing a request coming from the public Internet to a private resource. Important to note that all resources behind the API Gateway like your microservices and database should remain private and not being exposed to the Internet. Only API Gateway should have the ability to route the right request from the public to the private territory.

### Service Layer

That’s where the magic happens. Most of your business logic is contained at this level. If you have microservices architecture, different requests will go to different microservices. Depending on your use-case, your service can do any number of things like making a database query, calling another microservice or a 3rd party API, caching some data for future use, writing into a queue, or performing some computation.

## How to Build APIs Right

### Architecture

A properly architected system is at the core of a robust and scalable API. If your API is architected well, everything else comes together naturally. Your product will be able to support your level of traffic and you’ll have a lot of happy customers.

When designing your API, you’ll need to minimize the following:

1. A number of single points of failure (which is a database in most cases).
2. A number of internal calls between services.
3. Timing of each individual call.

The main thing to realize is that each call results in a chain of events. While the work is happening the user is waiting for a response. Time and time again we’ve seen a seemingly quick API call taking a long time or sometimes taking the system down. Everyone on the team needs to have a clear idea of which calls are made for each operation and which resources are used during each call. There are a lot of tools out there like [NewRelic](https://newrelic.com/ "NewRelic website") or [DataDog](https://www.datadoghq.com/ "DataDog page") that help you measure the timing of each individual call between services. You’ll be able to fix the issues before the software gets pushed to prod by instrumenting your app and running some [load tests](/solutions/automated-tests-get-dividends-with-every-test-run#load-tests) against it in your testing environment.

### Scalability

Once the system is architected for scale, supporting more traffic or less traffic should be as simple as a configuration change. Here are the main things to consider:

#### Scaling Automatically

Most of the cloud providers have auto-scaling capabilities based on certain rules you can specify. In addition to it, we recommend looking into [Serverless tech](/solutions/serverless-software-development-focus-on-features-instead-of-the-infrastructure) allowing for scaling automatically with the increase or decrease in traffic. If your server provisioning is manual at the moment, it’s worth thinking about automating it. This way you can spend your engineering resources on developing new features or improving the strength of the overall system instead of manually provisioning servers.

#### Minimize Service Chaining

Especially with microservices, it’s easy to fall into a trap of ‘nano services’. Making your services too granular can lead to an increase in the number of inner service calls. It’s a good idea to avoid making one service call another service and so on and so forth. The longer the call chain, the greater the possibility of a failure at each step, and the overall call length increases too. In addition to it, debugging a call spanning across multiple services is much harder than debugging a single call to a single service.

#### Alerting and Monitoring

Alerting and monitoring is your best friend. It should be a part of the requirement for every feature. When your alerting and monitoring are properly set up you sleep better at night. It allows you to be more proactive about fixing the issues before they become problems. If something goes wrong, you’ll get notified and you’ll stay ahead of the game. This also increases the accountability of your team. The systems need to be developed so they always work without human intervention.

A great book on a subject is [Art of Scalability](https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0134032802/ref=as_li_qf_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=howtoprogramb-20&creative=9325&linkCode=as2&creativeASIN=0134032802&linkId=55bea73bd8158a7441b84e4d4921bbb3 "The art of scalability book").

### Cost Efficiency

Your backend API is what makes your system scale to support a large number of users. With the increase in traffic comes the increase in cost. Therefore, when building your backend, you should be aware of the cost implications of your implementation decisions. We recommend focusing on the following areas:

#### Keeping your operational database slim

The main purpose of your operational database is to serve the immediate API requests. Anything else adds to the database size, decreases the database availability, and makes scaling the database harder, especially for SQL databases.

#### Keeping your non-production environments small

Depending on your use-case, you’ll need a number of different environments. For a simple scenario having just 3 environments works just fine (development, staging, and production). As your organization grows, you’ll have more use cases you need to support and the number of environments will grow too. The key here is to have all production and pre-production environments with the same configuration. And all the rest of the systems with a scaled-down version of your resources to keep the cost down. In addition to it, using Serverless or Containers helps to minimize idle server time.

#### Using the right tool for the job

We’ve seen many cases where a SQL database stores all application logs, acts as a search index for different kinds of queries, and even acts as a data warehouse while providing data for the API requests. There are solutions made specifically for each type of problem to solve. Logs can be archived into some flat files and processed offline. There are plenty of search solutions like [Elastic Search](https://www.elastic.co/ "Elastic Search page") or [Algolia](https://www.algolia.com/ "Algolia Website"). A data warehouse needs to be separate from your runtime operational database so your data analyst doesn’t bring your runtime system down. Plus data warehouse users need the data in a different format. When using the right solution for each type of problem, you’ll be able to provide a better experience for the users. You’ll also have better control over your system cost.

## Conclusion

Your backend infrastructure is the heart of your system. It supports your client applications at scale. Architecting your backend system right makes everything else easier. Using the right tool for the job is key. There are specialized solutions for each type of problem. The goal is to build it so it always works with some comprehensive alerting and monitoring in place notifying you about the issues in advance. If you need some help with building a robust backend API, don’t hesitate to reach out.

children.value: Traditional software development involves manual testing which works well on a small scale. That being said, once your team grows in size, engineers write more code, manually testing each new and existing feature is not effective anymore. Bugs get into production making customers unhappy. This is where automated testing comes in. Automated tests are a codified version of manual tests. The tests are written by engineers. Once they’re written they can run over and over again while your engineers are working on the text feature.

This is perhaps one of the most important advantages of automated testing. What makes testing easier is structuring your code in a modular way. Modularizing your architecture allows you to swap out or refactor each module in isolation without affecting the rest of the system.
In addition to your code being modular, your code will also be more robust. When running your tests with some randomized data or by using

, your code gets executed under different conditions. Seeing the code you wrote fail under some conditions you didn’t think about is eye-opening. It allows you to account for more edge cases and make your code more robust.

Your product changes, your customer change, and your code need to change as a result of it. Refactoring makes changing your code easier. Automated tests allow you to make sure your code works as expected once the refactor is complete. This way you can refactor without any fear of breaking your already working system.

Automated tests catch bugs. With the constantly growing amount of code, we humans are not able to keep all code paths in our heads which leads to unexpected bugs. Automated tests help exercise all code paths involved so you can focus on the task at hand as opposed to constantly retesting the entire system and hypothesizing where it can break.
Tests document the existing behavior of your system. When structured correctly, and especially with the use of
syntax, your tests are your system documentation. You can use it to ramp up new engineers as well as a reference for how your system works in practice.
Tests Prove That Your System Works

The code you write may be the greatest code ever and you may think it works. That being said, you never know if it actually works until it’s in production serving real customers. A green test suite is proof of your code working as expected as opposed to a guess or a good feeling that your system will work.
Get Dividends With Each Test Run

Writing automated tests is an investment that pays dividends with every test run. Once the test is written, there is no need to execute it again manually. You can run an automated test at any time on-demand, or have it running automatically on every new code change. Every time you run it, it makes sure your system behaves the way it should.

The main disadvantage of automated testing is that it makes a large sweeping change harder. If you’re writing a prototype, or your product didn’t achieve the product-market fit, then automated tests will get in the way of pivoting or making a full restructure change. Ironically, this is one of the most common reasons for not adopting automated testing. The teams we’ve seen tried to do it too early. After having some bad experience with it, they stopped testing altogether and never came back to it. Only discovering later that they wrote a lot of tightly coupled code that is hard to test.

Our recommendation is to double down on unit tests, write fewer integration tests, and fewer UI/API tests. Why? Because unit tests are the easiest to write, fastest to run, easiest to parallelize, and it forces you to produce a robust baseline for your modular architecture. Integration and unit tests have some great coverage. On another hand it’s hard to write integration tests, they are slower and more brittle. Let’s go over each kind of test in detail.

Unit tests test a specific unit of code. They’re usually isolated testing a specific class, a specific function, or a small group of classes and functions. Unit Tests are usually written by the engineers while the functionality is implemented. Most of the business logic is covered by unit tests. Since the unit of code under each test is relatively small, you can set up different conditions for each test. It works especially well when setting up each test with some randomized data. Unit tests are quickest to run, they are the easiest to parallelize and optimize. We recommend writing most of your test cases at the unit test level.

While unit tests test each unit of code in isolation, an integration test tests how multiple units work together. Due to a higher level of complexity, these tests are usually slower to run, harder to set up, and harder to parallelize. It’s also harder to test boundary conditions because the test set up is more complicated. That’s why we recommend writing fewer cases and structuring your integration tests to cover a larger number of integration points in each test.

UI Tests drive your GUI (i.e. click or tap actual buttons on the screen, etc) and API tests drive your API (i.e. sending real HTTP or GraphQL requests to your endpoints, etc). As you probably guessed UI or API tests are one of the slowest to run and the most complicated to set up. The reason is that they operate at the UI or API level which is usually just the tip of the iceberg. That being said, UI or API tests give you the most coverage for the number of tests. Here, we recommend going with a few happy paths to make sure everything behaves as needed, all screens render properly and all requests come back as normal.

Since you get the main benefit of automated tests when you execute it, your test suite is your best friend. The test suite runs all necessary tests in sequence parallelizing tests where it’s possible. Depending on your situation you may have several test suites running at different stages of the process. We recommend creating a robust
which runs before merging your feature branches and when you deploy your code.
As the name suggests, load tests test your system under load. There are numerous tools available starting from a simple CLI tool like
to more sophisticated solutions with a GUI like

. We recommend performing load testing in a separate environment similar in capacity to a production environment. This way we compare apples to apples. Before running the tests, make sure your monitoring is set up so you can see the metrics before, during, and after the test. Depending on your system, you might want to monitor your database throughput, CPU / Memory / Hard Disk usage of your application servers, etc.
How To Start With Automated Testing

All it takes is just starting to do it. If you don’t have a test suite running, getting it to run and putting it on CI is the first step. There are several ways to give the team visibility into the health of your automated tests. You can enable CI notifications about the failed builds to go to Slack. Another helpful technique is exposing the CI status as a dashboard on a TV in the office. Once you have your tests running seeing your test data will become eye-opening. Even if your test suite has just a few tests.

If you’re dealing with a monolithic tightly coupled system, the main thing is to start carving out some pieces of the monolith into smaller chunks which are easier to test in isolation. Step by step you’ll be able to take your system under control.
